awd_titl_txt: FET: Small: Collaborative Research: A Probability Correlator for All-Magnetic Probabilistic Computing: Theory and Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
Probabilistic computing is a computing paradigm that can solve certain problems more efficiently than traditional digital computing. While digital computing deals with deterministic binary bits that are either 0 or 1, probabilistic computing deals with probabilistic bits (p- bits) that are sometimes 0 and sometimes 1. This is distinct from quantum computing that deals with quantum bits (q-bits) which are a superposition of 0 and 1 (and hence a mixture of both 0 and 1 all the time). Quantum computing usually requires the most hardware resources and digital computing the least, with probabilistic computing between the two. Most of the hardware resources in probabilistic computing are devoted to generating specific correlations between two or more p-bit streams. This project will study and demonstrate a system that will greatly reduce the hardware burden associated with generating correlations. The results will make probabilistic computing much more efficient than it currently is. The project will educate K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students in this field to increase the pool of skilled scientists and engineers while advancing the field of computing.

One of the major challenges in probabilistic computing is the complex hardware needed to generate required correlations between probabilistic bit streams. This hardware usually consists of microcontrollers, analog-to-digital converters, shift registers, etc., that consume significant power and vastly expand the system’s footprint on a chip. In this project, an ultra-compact and extremely energy-efficient correlator or anti-correlator will be studied and demonstrated that can generate tunable degrees of anti-correlation between two p-bit streams. The approach is implemented with two magnetic tunnel junctions (MTJs) whose soft layers are in close proximity and hence dipole-coupled. Bit states are encoded in the resistance states (high or low) of the MTJs. One MTJ generates a p-bit when driven by a spin-polarized current delivering a spin-transfer-torque. The current sets the resistance state high or low with a probability determined by its magnitude, while the bit state of the other MTJ is determined by dipole coupling with the first. Very strong dipole coupling will result in perfect anti-correlation, while very weak dipole coupling will result in no correlation. The effect of dipole coupling will be controlled by applying (electrically generated) local strain to the second MTJ, which modulates its internal energy barrier, thereby modulating the degree of anti-correlation between the p-bits from 0% to 100%. This project will result in new understanding of devices that use emerging nanomagnetic physics for the next generation of computing.

por.por_cntn:
This project was centered on developing magnetic materials and devices to design probabilistic (p) bit based Boltzmann machines. A Boltzmann machine is a graph that uses stochasticity to efficiently compute, with applications in deep learning and AI. But, a Boltzmann machine is complicated to set up using standard silicon based computing, limiting its practical use. Instead, the properties of physical systems can be leveraged to efficiently compute in this way. P-bits, i.e. probabilistic bits, can be constructed using the naturally stochastic dynamics of magnetic materials, in particular magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) memory devices. But, controlling these MTJs traditionally takes high currents or voltages. 

In this project, we carried out materials science research and device research towards creating MTJ p-bit Boltzmann machines that can be controlled using strain. Voltage-induced strain is theoretically a highly energy- efficient method for switching magnetization in magnetic nanodevices, predicted to be dissipating 1000 times lower energy compared to current-driven methods and at least 10 times lower energy compared to other voltage-driven methods. Strain can also be used in conjunction with other switching methods to increase the tunability of the MTJ resistance states for application in Boltzmann machines.

One challenge to this goal is that most standard magnetic materials used in MTJs do not have a strong response to strain. Some magnetic materials are highly magnetostrictive, such as the ferromagnet FeGa, but are challenging to integrate into the MTJ thin film stack. In the materials science portion of the project, research on materials growth and characterization was carried out to integrate FeGa into the MTJ thin film stack. Ga diffusion was analyzed after post-growth heating, and this diffusion was minimized through adding Ru interlayers to the stack. The project successfully resulted in FeGa-MTJs with maintained on/off ratio of the memory element. In addition to integrating FeGa for strain-controlled probabilistic applications, the results also showed that the FeGe can operate in multiple ways, for example as both the fixed layer of the MTJ device and as the free layer, increasing the application space of the results. In a follow-on work, the project studied MTJs grown on a piezoelectric substrate. Challenges with MTJ growth on this rougher substrate were brought to light, but the project was still able to result in preliminary results of MTJ on/off ratio linearly responsive to the substrate voltage, showing a path towards application in Boltzmann machines.

An experimental study was conducted to examine the effect of time varying strain on the switching characteristics of a straintronic MTJ (s-MTJ). The time varying strain was generated by launching a surface acoustic wave (SAW) in the piezoelectric substrate of the s-MTJ. Several surprising features were observed: (1) there is a strong size dependence (nm-scale MTJs are less sensitive to SAW than mm-sized MTJs); (2) the tunneling magneto-resistance (TMR) can be negative (!) meaning that the off-state resistance is lower than the on-state resistance.

We theoretically studied strain engineering to reconfigure a binary stochastic neuron (BSN), implemented with a low barrier nanomagnet (LBM), to an analog stochastic neuron (ASN) and vice versa. BSNs are useful for solving a class of combinatorial optimization problem using Ising/Boltzmann machines, while ASNs are useful for solving another class of problems like time series prediction. The ability to reconfigure a BSN to an ASN, and vice versa, on-chip with a gate leads to an extremely powerful architecture for solving a wide class of NP-hard problems. We also devised a way to increase the speed of probabilistic computers.

We reported a new method for noise engineering with application in communication systems. The noise is emulated by the magnetization fluctuation in a nanomagnet. The fluctuation mimics “telegraph noise” if the nanomagnet is not stressed. If we apply stress, the fluctuation begins to acquire the characteristic of white noise with a different power spectrum than telegraph noise.

Taken together, these results have impacted the discipline of electrical and computer engineering to build new computers that can efficiently accomplish deep learning and AI tasks. We showed key materials science results for leveraging magnetostrictive and piezoelectric materials for p-bits. This improved understanding of magnetic systems has broad impacts in the many areas that magnetic nanodevices are being applied, including memory, neuromorphic computing, and probabilistic computing. In turn, these areas will impact all areas of advanced compute, from high-performance compute in data centers, to efficient compute in edge devices.

This project has also trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students, including 3 female students, increasing and diversifying the US workforce in microelectronics. For example, one graduate student received her Ph.D. in July 2023 and is now working at Applied Materials. The project has also built bridges between the magnetism and nanoelectronics communities, for example through service with the International Magnetic Random Access Memory (MRAM) Forum and through the PI’s and co-PI’s leadership in publishing a roadmap for unconventional computing.
